raw_text:
Search sites get closer to users
 
 Search sites want to get to know you better.
 
 Not content with providing access to the millions of websites, many now offer ways that do a better job of remembering, cataloguing and managing all the information you come across. Some of the latest to update their search systems are Ask Jeeves and Blinkx, which have both released a series of utilities that try to help people get more from the web. "The future is all about developing your own personal web," said Tony Macklin, spokesman for Ask Jeeves.
 
 Mr Macklin said that too often when people use a search engine it was like the first time they ever used it, because there was no memory of what they had searched for before. "Each time you go back in you have to start all over again," he said. The series of updates to its service, collected under the My Ask Jeeves banner, would help people remember where they had been before.
 
 Ask Jeeves has added the ability to "save" websites of interest so the next time a users visits the site they can search through the sites they have previously found. Sites saved in this way can be arranged in folders and have notes attached to them to explain why they were saved. Mr Macklin said many people wanted to save sites they had seen but did not want to add them to their bookmarks or favourites not least because such lists cannot be easily searched. On average, said Mr Macklin, users conduct between five and 10 searches per day and the tools in My Ask Jeeves should stop them having to do searches twice and get to what they want much more easily. Under My Ask Jeeves users can search the web or through the results they have already noted as interesting. "It's about finding again what you found before," he said. The My Ask Jeeves service lets people store up to a 1000 web links or 5000 if they sign up to the free service. By way of comparison Google's Desktop search tool catalogues search histories informally and lets people look through the sites they have visited.
 
 At the same time, search start-up Blinkx has released a second version of its eponymous software. Blinkx is desktop search software that watches what someone is working on, be it a document or e-mail, and suggests websites, video clips, blogs or documents on a PC that are relevant to it.
 
 Since Blinkx launched it has faced increased competition from firms such as Google, Copernic, Enfish, X1 and Apple all of whom now have programs that let people search their PC as well as the web. "The competition has validated the problem we tackle," said Suranga Chandratillake, co-founder of Blinkx. In the latest release of Blinkx, the company has added what it calls smart folders. Once created the folders act as persistent queries that automatically sweep the web for pages related to their subject and catalogues relevant information, documents or incoming e-mails, on hard drives too. What users do with Blinkx and other desktop search engines shows that people tend to be very promiscuous in their use of search engines. "Blinkx users do not stop using other web search systems," he said. "They might use Google to look up a company, or Yahoo for travel because they know they are good at that," he said. "The classic thing we have seen recently, is people using Blinkx to look at the things they have searched on," he said. The variety of ways to search data was only helping users, said Mr Chandratillake and that it was likely that in the future people would use different ones for different tasks.
llama3.2:1b: Search sites are developing tools to help users remember where they've been and what they've looked at online.
These tools allow users to save websites of interest, organize them into folders with notes explaining why they were saved, and search through previously noted interests.
In addition, some search engines like Ask Jeeves and Blinkx have updated their services to improve user experience by allowing users to save websites and return to previous searches more easily.
These tools can also be used for different tasks, such as saving documents or browsing the web.
Search start-up Blinkx has released a new version of its software that watches what someone is working on and suggests relevant information.
The company's co-founder notes that users tend to use multiple search engines depending on their needs, but still return to their favorite ones for specific searches.
llama3.2:3b: Search engines are updating their systems to better remember user information, such as websites visited and searched for.
Ask Jeeves has added a feature to save websites of interest with notes, while Blinkx has released software that suggests relevant sites based on what users are working on.
Both companies aim to make searching the web more efficient by cataloguing search histories and providing persistent queries.
gemma2:2b: Search sites are developing tools that allow users to save websites of interest, organize them into folders, and easily revisit previous searches.
Ask Jeeves and Blinkx have introduced such features that enable more efficient web browsing and provide a personalized approach to online exploration.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Search sites are getting closer to users because they want to get to know you better through features such as remembering websites, cataloguing and managing information.
Some search engines offer these services, while others are developing their own tools.

Tony Macklin, a spokesman for Ask Jeeves, says that people often forget where they searched before they visit a new website, so many companies have developed ways to help users remember the places they've been.
Ask Jeeves allows users to "save" websites they've previously found, and creates folders and notes to organize them into categories.
Blinkx, another search engine, has developed smart folders that automatically look up relevant pages based on what the user is working on.
Both services show how people tend to use their web browsers and other search engines.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Search engines aim to enhance user experience by improving personalization and memory functions.
Ask Jeeves adds "My Ask Jeeves" service to remember past searches and catalog relevant websites, reducing redundant searching.
Blinkx's second version introduces smart folders that categorize related information on a PC based on activities like working on documents or emails.
Both companies recognize competition from other search engines but emphasize their unique features.
Users frequently switch between different search systems for specific needs.
qwen2.5:3b: Search sites aim to provide better user experiences by remembering and managing the information users come across.
Updates like Ask Jeeves' My Ask Jeeves and Blinkx's smart folders aim to help users recall previously visited websites or content, reducing repetitive searches.
Both services offer features such as saving interesting web pages for later use and organizing them in folders with notes.
Google also offers desktop search tools for managing history data and searching previously noted sites.

As competition increases among search engines, including those like Google, Copernic, Enfish, X1, and Apple's programs, the value of personalized search services is validated, as users often continue to use other web search systems but might turn to specific ones based on their expertise for certain tasks.
This variety in search methods can lead to more effective data management and task-specific searches in the future.
opencoder:1.5b: Search sites want to get closer to you, providing access to the millions of websites that do a better job of remembering, cataloguing and managing all the information you come across.
Blinkx has released a series of utilities that help users get more from the web, saving their searches for later reference.
"Too often when people use a search engine it feels like first time they used it," said Tony Macklin.

In the latest release of Blinkx, smart folders let users store up to 1,000 websites or 5,000 if they sign up to the free service, but by way of comparison Google's Desktop search tool catalogues search histories informally and lets people look through the sites they have visited.
smollm:1.7b:
Summarize the following text concisely:
Search sites get closer to users by providing better access to information they've already found on the web.
Not content with providing access to the millions of websites, many now offer ways that do a better job of remembering, cataloguing and managing all the information you come across.
Some of the latest to update their search systems are Ask Jeeves and Blinkx, which have both released utilities that try to help people get more from the web.
"The future is all about developing your own personal web," said Tony Macklin, spokesman for Ask Jeeves.
Not content with providing access to the web, many users now use search engines like Google or Bing to find information they've already found on the web.
Search engines like Google and Bing are designed to help people quickly find what they're looking for by storing up to 100 million web pages in their databases.
By saving these web pages, users can recall them later when they need to search again.
This is known as "caching" and it's a key feature of many search engines.
Search engines like Google or Bing are designed to help people quickly find what they've already found on the web by storing up to 100 million web pages in their databases.
By saving these web pages, users can recall them later when they need to search again.
This is known as "caching" and it's a key feature of many search engines.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Search sites aim to become more personalized, offering services like Ask Jeeves and Blinkx that enhance user experience through features such as saving saved sites and using smart folders for better search results.
These platforms compete with major search engines like Google by providing innovative tools that help users find information efficiently.
tinyllama:1.1b: Search sites are getting closer to users by offering new personalized tools such as Ask Jeeves' My Ask Jeeves service and Blinkx's Eponymous software, which allows users to search their PCs as well as the web for specific content.
The updates aim to help people remember where they have been before and catalogue sites of interest so they can easily access them again.

Users tend to be promiscuous in using seaRCH engines, with Blinkx's smart folders allowing for automatic search queries and categorisation of relevant information, documents or incoming e-mails on hard drives.
However, the variety of tasks users use seaRCH tools for is likely to continue contributing to a more personalized experience.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Search sites are getting closer to users by providing more personalized experiences through features like saving websites and searching history with My Ask Jeeves.
These tools help users remember what they've seen before, which can save them time and effort when looking up something they've already encountered.
Blinkx is also introducing smart folders that allow users to organize their web search results and automatically catalog relevant information, documents or incoming e-mails.
This makes searching for specific topics quicker and more effective.
phi:2.7b: Search sites are improving by offering ways to remember and manage information found online.

Ask Jeeves and Blinkx are two examples of companies providing tools to help users get more from the web, such as being able to save websites they have previously searched or adding them to a folder for easy access in future searches.

These updates aim to reduce the need for users to start their search engine from scratch every time they want to find something and instead rely on their previous searches to guide them quickly to what they are looking for.

In order to understand the efficiency of different types of search engines, let's consider a hypothetical situation: 

There are five top-ranking search engines - Google, Bing, Yahoo, Ask Jeeves, and Blinkx.

A group of web developers each use one of these search engines for their work and they have provided feedback about its performance based on the following parameters: Accuracy (A), Speed (S), Flexibility (F), Ease of Use (E), Memory Usage (M).
Ask Jeeves is used by a web developer who finds its accuracy higher than Blinkx, but lower than Google.
Yahoo does not have the highest or lowest memory usage.
Bing provides faster search results than any other engine and has better speed than Yahoo.

The engine with the best flexibility uses more memory than the one used by the web developer who finds its accuracy higher than Yahoo, but lesser than the one used by the web developer using Ask Jeeves.
Blinkx is not used for its memory usage, it provides faster results than Bing and has better speed than Yahoo.
Google provides the highest flexibility.
The engine used by a web developer who finds its accuracy higher than that of Yahoo uses more memory than the one which is used by the developer using Ask Jeeves.
The one with the best ease of use uses less memory than the one which uses Blinkx but has better speed than Google.
The question is: Can you rank these engines based on the parameters given, from most to least optimal for a web developer?
Based on the information provided, we can start by creating a tree of thought reasoning.
We know that Ask Jeeves uses more memory than Yahoo (and less than Google) and Blinkx uses less memory than the one used by the web developer using Ask Jeeves but has better speed.
From this, we can infer that, in terms of memory usage: Google < Ask Jeeves < Blinkx < Web Developer Using Yahoo < Web Developer Using Ask Jeeves and Yahoo.

Using inductive logic, we know Bing provides faster search results than any other engine and uses more memory than the one used by Yahoo but has better speed than Yahoo, which means it lies somewhere in-between Yahoo and Google in terms of memory usage.
From this information, we can infer that Google is the best in flexibility since it doesn't use less or more memory than any other engine.
It provides higher accuracy than Ask Jeeves, so it's not the one used by the web developer using Ask Jeeves.
Using transitivity, if Google uses less memory than Bing and Blinkx uses less memory than Yahoo, then Google must use less memory than both of them.
Hence, we can infer that Google also provides faster results than Blinkx (which uses less memory than Yahoo).
This means Blinkx is the one with the most flexibility since it's not the best in speed or accuracy and uses more memory than Yahoo but has better speed than Yahoo.
Since Google provides higher accuracy than Ask Jeeves, this implies that Ask Jeeves has more flexibility than Yahoo (using less memory).
This leaves us with Bing as the best for speed and accuracy since the other two criteria are already taken by Google and Ask Jeeves respectively.

Hence, using direct proof, we can assert that the engine used by a web developer who finds its accuracy higher than Yahoo uses more memory than the one which is used by the developer using Ask Jeeves (which in turn uses less memory than Yahoo).
This also means the web developer has to be using Blinkx or Google.

Finally, using proof by contradiction, if we assume that Google and Ask Jeeves can't both have flexibility as highest (Google - accuracy > Ask Jeeves), it contradicts our information that Google is not the best in flexibility and hence this assumption is false.
Answer: The optimal search engines from most to least for a web developer are Google, Blinkx, Yahoo, Bing, and Ask Jeeves respectively.
orca-mini:3b: Search sites want to get to know their users better by providing ways to remember where they have been before.
Some search engines like Ask Jeeves are updating their systems to make this happen.
The My Ask Jeeves service lets people store up to 1000 web links or 5000 if they sign up to the free service.
It also allows users to search through the sites they have visited and find what they want again.

Competing search start-ups like Blinkx have updated their software with smart folders that automatically sweep the web for pages related to a subject and catalogues relevant information on the hard drive.
Users tend to use multiple search engines and Blinkx is one of them.
The variety of ways to search data is helping users, says Mr Chandratillake, and in the future people will use different ones for different tasks.
hermes3:3b: Ask Jeeves and Blinkx updates offer personalized search systems to remember user interests, allowing easier retrieval of saved websites and potentially relevant information from a desktop catalog.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Search sites like Ask Jeeves and Blinkx aim to improve memory and organization by remembering and cataloging information users come across.
Ask Jeeves allows saving websites of interest, arranged in folders with notes.
Blinkx suggests relevant websites based on the user's current activity, such as documents or emails.
These services compete with other search engines that let people search their PC and the web.
The variety of search methods is beneficial to users and it is likely they will use different ones for different tasks in the future.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Search sites are evolving to better remember, catalog, and manage user information.
Ask Jeeves introduced "My Ask Jeeves," allowing users to save and organize websites for easier retrieval, reducing redundant searches.
Users can store up to 1,000 links or 5,000 with a free account.
Meanwhile, Blinkx updated its desktop search software, which tracks user activity and suggests relevant content.
The new version includes "smart folders" that continuously gather related web pages and documents.
Blinkx competes with Google, Apple, and others but sees users employing multiple search tools for different needs.
The trend suggests a future where users rely on various search engines for specific tasks.
stablelm2:1.6b: Search sites are working towards providing a better user experience by improving their search systems.
Ask Jeeves and Blinkx have introduced utilities aimed at enhancing web browsing.
Ask Jeeves offers features to save previously visited websites, allowing users to revisit and search through saved sites without starting from scratch.
Blinkx, which provides desktop search capabilities, has added smart folders that automatically monitor and catalog relevant data on hard drives.
Users are becoming increasingly promiscuous in their use of search engines, using different ones for different tasks.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Search sites are enhancing their services to better remember and manage user-searched information.
Ask Jeeves has introduced My Ask Jeeves, a feature allowing users to save and organize up to 1000 or 5000 web links, respectively for free or premium users.
Users can categorize saved sites with notes, facilitating quicker access to previously discovered content without repetitive searches.
Blinkx, a search start-up, has also released its second version, which watches user activities on their PC and suggests relevant websites, videos, blogs, or documents.
The updated Blinkx features smart folders, which function as persistent queries, automatically gathering related web content for cataloging on hard drives.

Both Ask Jeeves and Blinkx cater to users' diverse search needs across various platforms, reflecting the trend of promiscuous search engine usage and highlighting the potential for tailored search solutions in the future.
